Dialogue: Holmes, let me ask you a question --  I hope I'm not being presumptuous -- but there have been women in your life?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: The answer is yes.  Good night.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes...

Speaker: watson's voice
Dialogue: What, indeed, was his attitude toward women? Was there some secret he was holding back -- or was he just a thinking machine, incapable of any emotion?

Speaker: watson's voice
Dialogue: I was not to get the answer until we became involved in what I consider to be the most outrageous case in all our years together.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Were you expecting someone?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Not at this hour.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Maybe Mrs. Hudson is entertaining.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: I never found her so.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: What is it, Mrs. Hudson?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: For what?

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: For the fare, guv'nor. The young lady doesn't have any money.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: What young lady?

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: This one.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Well.  What have we here?  Who are you, miss? What happened to you?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: That's all she keeps saying -- I don't know, I don't know.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Where did she come from?

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: From the river. I was driving down the Embankment, just below Westminster Bridge, and there she was in the water -- drowning.

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: It wasn't easy, guv'nor -- what with the cold water -- and her fighting me --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Why did you bring her here?

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: Because I found this in her hand --  -- 221B Baker Street -- that's right, isn't it?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Young lady -- what did you want at this address?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I do not remember.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Rather perplexing, wouldn't you say?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Rather.

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: Well, gentlemen, you want her? -- it's two-and-six -- or shall I throw her back in the river?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Watson, you'd better accept delivery.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Keep the change.

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: Thank you, guv'nor.

Speaker: cabbie
Dialogue: No extra charge for the use of the horse- blanket.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: You're shivering, my dear.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Sit here, my dear.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: She's suffering from shock and exposure.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: There was some printing on the back of this -- but it seems to have come off in the water.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Look at this -- she's had a nasty blow on the head.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: No. The blood has already coagulated. So it would appear that she was the victim of a deliberate attack... Get my bag, will you?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I'm Dr. Watson -- and this is Mr. Sherlock Holmes. Do the names mean anything to you?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Think.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I'm trying.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Can you think of your own name?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: She's obviously had a concussion -- which often leads to temporary amnesia.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: So all we know is that she was coshed on the head, dumped into the Thames, and subsequently dumped into our laps.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: We know a lot more than that. From her accent, we know she is foreign -- from her ring, we know she is married -- and there is one other clue we have... Something I deduced while I was helping her up the stairs. No corset.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Good work.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Vous etes Francaise?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Non, je ne suis pas Francaise.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: How can she say she's not French, in French?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Vous etes Suisse?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Non.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Alors, vous etes Belge.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Je suis pas sure.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Vous etes Belge -- de Bruxelles!

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Bruxelles?    Oui... Je pense que oui.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: We just found out that she's Belgian.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: From Brussels.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: If you don't mind.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Your name is Gabrielle, is that right? Gabrielle?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: And your husband's name is Emile?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Emile...

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Where is he? What are you doing in London?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: When did you arrive from Brussels?     Where are you staying?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: What happened at the river?   Think! Pensez! Concentrez vous!

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I'll sleep on the couch.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I'd better mix her a sleeping potion.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Watson, I think we should arrange to have her removed to a hospital.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Under no circumstances.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: She should have medical attention.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: She can get that from me. But more importantly, she must be protected -- there has already been one attempt on her life.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: This temporary amnesia -- how temporary is it?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: It depends on the extent of the injury. It's like veils shrouding her memory. It could clear up in a few days -- or a few weeks.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Watson, this is a very small flat -- we don't want to clutter it up with women...

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes, we've never had a case like this. A woman comes to us with a problem -- we don't know who the woman is -- and we don't know what the problem is. Don't you find that challenging?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Quite. But we can't afford to wait for those veils to lift -- we must break through them as quickly as possible.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: You   really feel it's that urgent?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: I do. The sooner we solve the case, the sooner we can get rid of her.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Emile?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Emile?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Emile?   Is that you, Emile?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Yes, Gabrielle.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: It's been such a long time. So many nights. You know what I did before I left Brussels?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I hope you won't be angry with me. I bought myself an expensive negligee.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Did you?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Come.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Where is the negligee?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: In my luggage... Come here.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: And where is your luggage?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I don't know. Come, my love.   Come. Please.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: What is it, Emile? What are you doing?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I would like to very much. But --  Mrs. Hudson, would you mind planting your knee in the small of my back?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Please!   I'm in excruciating pain.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: A bit higher -- just below my seventh vertebra --  That's good. Put your arms under mine -- fold them behind my neck --

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Bless you.  You'd better see if our patient is awake.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Gone?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes!   Holmes! She's gone!

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Mmmmm. I smell porridge.   Lumpy as usual, I suppose.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Oh, there you are, Holmes. We were just wondering -- how --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Mrs. Hudson, why don't you go down to the kitchen -- get a towel -- and wipe that look of disapproval off your face.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: You can't really blame her -- I mean, the way it looks -- if I didn't know you better, I might suspect you'd taken advantage of the young lady.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: As a matter of fact, I did take advantage of her... Would you hand me the butter- knife, please?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: You did what?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes, this is reprehensible! Where are your professional ethics? Have you no sense of decency, no shame --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: None whatsoever. If you must know, I found her body quite rewarding.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: You cad!

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Especially the palm of her right hand.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I'd rather not hear about it!

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Very well. Then I won't bother to tell you how I traced her suitcase.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: That's her suitcase?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Remember that piece of soggy cardboard with our address on it? It was a luggage ticket -- the number rubbed off on her hand. And since she must have arrived from Brussels by the boat train, I concluded that she had checked her belongings at Victoria Station.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: By Jove! If you're right, we should find a clue to her identity.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Or at least a pink negligee with maribou feathers.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Voila!

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Let's see - what else is in here?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Now we're getting somewhere.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Who do you suppose this is?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Come in, Madame Valladon.  You are Gabrielle Valladon.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: And this is your husband, Emile Valladon?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Sorry to have ransacked your valise.     But since you came to us for help --

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Where am I?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: 221B Baker Street.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Oh, yes...  Which of you is Mr. Holmes and which is Dr. Watson?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Dr. Watson is the handsome one.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: That's the way he affects most women.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Coffee. You want strong coffee.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: It's all so confusing.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Let's try to sort it out. You came to London looking for your husband...

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Yes. He's a mining engineer. We were married five years ago, in the Congo.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Where your husband was working in a copper mine.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: How did you know?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Your wedding ring -- it's made of copper.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Last year he invented a new kind of air pump, and was hired by an English company, Jonah Limited.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Here you are.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Jonah Limited. Go on.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: We've been writing to each other regularly. Then suddenly,  three weeks ago, his letters stopped.  I kept writing ... but no answer. Finally  I decided to go to that address --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: 32 Ashdown Street.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Yes. It's just an empty store -- nobody there. Then I tried to find Jonah Limited. No such company exists.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: How decidedly odd.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Madame Valladon, can you think of any reason why your husband should have lied to you about theses things?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Emile?   Never. He loves me -- and I love him.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: So I gathered.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I went to the police -- they said they would send out a missing persons report -- but they didn't sound too encouraging. Then I went to the Belgian embassy and explained the situation to them -- and they suggested that I consult you...

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: You could have done worse.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I was on my way here -- and suddenly there were footsteps behind me -- and a hand over my mouth -- and the smell of choloroform -- and the next thing I knew I was in the water -- and then a man was wrapping me in a blanket --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Madame Valladon, somebody tried to kill you last night. Do you have any idea who could have done it?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I don't understand any of it.  What does it all mean, Mr. Holmes? Where is my husband? You must help me find him.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: We'll do our best, I assure you.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Madame Valladon, I want you to send one more letter to your husband.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: To Emile Valladon -- Ashdown Street -- what was that number?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: 32. What do you want me to say in the letter?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Nothing.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: You're sending an empty sheet of paper to an empty shop?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: That empty shop is obviously    being used as an accomodation address,    or letter- drop. But what gets dropped     must be picked up. The question is     how? -- and by whom? -- and why?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Hammer... Chisel.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Here!

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: It's so strange to think I've been writing to a place like this all these months.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Look at all these canaries. Do you suppose this could have been a pet shop?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Maybe.  Here comes our letter.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Now we are faced with the most nerve- wracking part of the detective's job -- doing nothing.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Mr. Holmes --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I don't know how I'm going to pay you for all this. The purse with my money is somewhere at the bottom of the Thames.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: It could be worse. You could be at the bottom of the Thames -- much to your discomfort -- and much to my chagrin.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I don't understand how anybody picks up letters here.  No footprints -- just tracks. What does it mean?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: I would surmise somebody is using ice- skates -- if it weren't for a conspicuous absence of ice.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: What do we do now?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: This way.

Speaker: first carter
Dialogue: Morning, Duchess.

Speaker: second carter
Dialogue: What have you been doing with yourself?

Speaker: first carter
Dialogue: Two dozen.

Speaker: second carter
Dialogue: Look, Duchess, we don't know -- and we don't want to know.

Speaker: first carter
Dialogue: When you work for Jonah, it's better not to ask questions.

Speaker: first carter
Dialogue: ... twenty-two, twenty-three, twenty- four.

Speaker: second carter
Dialogue: How about that letter? Does that go, too?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I really thought we were done for.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: The art of concealment, my dear Watson, is merely a matter of being in the right place at the right time.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Did you hear what she said? You really think Emile is going to pick up the letter himself?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: It certainly would simplify things, wouldn't it?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Maildrops and canaries and wheelchairs... And what was all that about Jonah? And what do you suppose they're doing up there? And where is up there?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: My guess would be Scotland.   Inverness, to be more precise.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Inverness?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Didn't you notice the paper at the bottom of their cage? The Inverness Courier.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Mr. Holmes! This letter --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: What about it?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: It's addressed to you.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Nevertheless --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: What time do you make it, Watson?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Either your watch is wrong, or Mycroft has miscalculated. And knowing Mycroft, I suggest you reset your watch.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I don't mind telling you I'm a bit apprehensive about this.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: I'm rather curious myself as to what is going on in that Machiavellian mind of his.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I don't mean Mycroft, I mean Madame Valladon.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Don't worry.    She's perfectly safe with Mrs. Hudson.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: To see Mr. Mycroft Holmes.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Right you are. He's expecting you in the upstairs study. Now if you gentlemen will sign in --  Surname, Christian name, address, nature of business --

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Gentlemen...!

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Jamaican, no doubt -- either Tropical or Golosina -- I'm not quite sure.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: You're looking very fit, both of you.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: And how are you, Mycroft? How's your gout?

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Under control. Except for the occasional twinge.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: I have a treat for you -- a very old Madeira -- 1814. There are  only six bottles left in the world.  I have two of them, and am negotiating for a third.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: If you don't mind my saying so, anybody who's susceptible to gout shouldn't be --

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: The last doctor who warned me about that was crossing Piccadilly, slipped on an orange peel, and was run over by a delivery van from the Fortnum and Mason. Your very good health.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Why are you wasting this precious stuff on us?

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Well, I see you so rarely. How long has it been? Not since the case of the Greek interpreter.  Isn't it ridiculous? Two brothers living in the same town...

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: In the same town, perhaps -- but not the same world.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Mmmm.    Superb. How old did you say it was?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: One year before Waterloo?    Think of that.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: You do know where Waterloo is, don't you, Doctor?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Belgium, isn't it?

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Quite.  And speaking of Belgium, it has come to my attention that you are interested in the whereabouts of a certain engineer.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Yes, I am.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Well, I can save you a lot of trouble.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: I'd be grateful for any suggestion --

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: My suggestion is that you pursue it no further.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Any particular reason?

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Because it involves the national security. We are handling this matter ourselves.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: We?   Who's we?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: The Diogenes Club, of course.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: I didn't say that.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: I have always suspected that there was some underground connection between this stodgy and seemingly calcified establishment and the Foreign Office in Whitehall.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: That's neither here nor there.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: It seems to me that The Diogenes Club is here, there and everywhere. When there are rumblings of revolt in the Sudan, an expedition subsidized by your club conveniently shows up to study the source of the Nile. When there is trouble along the Indian frontier, some of your fellow members pop up in the Himalayas, alledgedly looking for the Abominable Snowman.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: What a fertile imagination my brother has. At the age of five, by carefully observing a neighbor's house, he deduced that babies were brought not by the stork, but by the mid-wife in her satchel.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: As good an explanation as any.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Yes, Wiggins?

Speaker: young man
Dialogue: An immediate answer is requested, sir.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Tell them that the three boxes go to Glennahurich, and the red runner goes to the castle.

Speaker: young man
Dialogue: The three boxes to Glennahurich, the red runner to the castle. Very good, sir.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Why don't you crumple it up and swallow it -- to make sure.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: My dear Sherlock, there  are certain affairs that do not come  within the province of the private  detective. They have to be dealt with on  an altogether different level.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: In other words, you want me to stay within my limits.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: I do indeed.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Speaking of limits, what exactly is Jonah Limited?

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Sherlock, when I said drop this case, it was not merely a suggestion -- it was an order!

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: By whose authority?

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: By the authority of Her Majesty's government. I hope I've made myself clear.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Perfectly.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Now if you'll excuse me, gentlemen --

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Goodbye, sir.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: A pleasure, as always.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: You forgot your tool-kit.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: You will be gentle, won't you, when you tell her you're dropping the case?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Watson, what does the word Glennahurich suggest to you?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Absolutely nothing.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: It's Scottish.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Is it?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: And like all Scottish names, it's really a word picture. Glen means valley, na means of the, and Hurich, if memory serves me, means yew tree.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: You're just trying to impress me.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: So the three boxes go to the Valley of the Yew Tree.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: You are dropping the case, aren't you, Holmes?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Open the door.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Don't shoot, Mrs. Hudson -- you're liable to lose two excellent tenants.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Why?   What happened?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: You'll be relieved to know it was not loaded.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes, you didn't answer my  question. Are you planning to disobey  Mycroft's orders? He's not just your   brother, you know. You'd be defying Her   Majesty's government...

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Any news?   Did you find out anything?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Let's just say I know what the next step will be.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: I want you to pack your things.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Where are we going?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes, let me caution you ---

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: At 7:30 this evening, Dr. Watson and I are going to take you to Victoria Station, and put you on the boat-train.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: The boat-train?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Well, that's better.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: You're sending me back to Brussels?   Is that it?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Madame Valladon, you must understand...

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I came here to find my husband -- you were going to help me --

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Yes, my dear. But circumstances have changed --

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: The great detective! Well, maybe this case is too small for you --

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: On the contrary. It's being handled at a much higher level --

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Well, I won't go back to Brussels. Maybe you're giving up, but I'm not.  I'm going to go on looking for him. And nobody's going to stop me -- even if they try to kill me.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Are you quite finished? If you recall, what I said was that we're going to put you on the boat-train -- I didn't say you were going to stay on it.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: She's not?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: At 7:30, Mr. Holmes and Dr. Watson will be seen waving goodbye to Madame Valladon at Victoria Station. At eight-twelve, Mr. and Mrs. Ashdown accompanied by their valet John --  -- will appear at Euston Station, and board the Highland Express to Inverness.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Mr. and Mrs.... ?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: That's not necessary.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I'll go and pack.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Maybe I should do it, since I'm the valet.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes, what exactly are you up to?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: As you like to put it in your chronicles, the game is afoot.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: But what game? Are you really that interested in the Belgian engineer?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Or the wife of the Belgian engineer?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: You don't like me very much, do you?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Nothing of the sort. Quite the opposite... But there's more to this case than meets the eye --

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Looking for something?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: My other glove.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Let me help you.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Here it is.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: All right.    You can look now.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Am I embarrassing you, Mr. Holmes?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Not at all. Would it surprise you if I told you I once spent the night with 121 women?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Oh?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: On a very interesting case -- in a harem in Constantinople.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Sorry, father -- I mean, friar -- or is it abbot?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Going to Scotland, you gentlemen?   So are we...

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I'm a valet. My master and mistress and I are our way to Inverness. Ever been there? Beautiful country.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Oh, forgive me. You must be one of those orders that's taken the vow of silence. Trappists, I believe you're called.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I see you're reading the book of Jonah. Funny - we were just talking about Johan this morning...  Never mind.

Dialogue: We have conclusive proof, Ma'am. Our agent in Friedrichshafen, a man named Ibbetson, actually saw the dirigible, and made a drawing of it. Unfortunately, he was apprehended before he could cross the border.

Speaker: queen victoria
Dialogue: Nevertheless, we don't want any part of this beastly invention. Get rid of it! Scuttle it! The sooner the better.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: May I point out, Ma'am --

Speaker: queen victoria
Dialogue: And don't concern yourself about that dirigible dropping bombs on us. We shall write a very sharp note to the Kaiser.  Now we wish to return to Balmoral.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Well, Mycroft, it seems we have both been undone by a woman.  What a shame.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Not necessarily. If the Germans want that submersible so badly, why don't we give it to them?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Give it to them?

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Invite them aboard for the final journey -- seven hundred feet -- straight down.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: And how are you going to arrange that?

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: I'm rather counting on you to do it. Since you are on such intimate terms with Fraulein von Hoffmanstal.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Shall we say goodbye to Her Majesty?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Sorry about that. But as long as you're up -- what is the German word for castle? Schloss, isn't it?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: And how would you say under the castle? Unter das Schlss? Or die Schloss?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I don't know. My German isn't that good.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Come now. It's too late to play cat and mouse.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Unter dem Schloss.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Thank you.  I only hope my Morse code is adequate to the occasion.  Keeping well to one side of the open window, he extends the parasol outside, opens it, starts sending out a series of long and short signals.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Well, it's up to the good monks now. You can consider your part of the mission accomplished, Fraulein Hoffmanstal.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: You're all wrong about me.   My name isn't Hoffmanstal.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: It isn't?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: It's von Hoffmanstal.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: I stand corrected.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I suppose once they're in the castle... It must amuse you, Mr. Holmes, Trappists walking into a trap.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: It's more amusing than that. Once in the castle, they will encounter surprisingly little resistance -- it will take but a small bottle of chloroform to overcome the guards.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: You mean you're going to let them have the air-pump?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Better than that. We're going to let them have the submersible. They will find it with its engines running, all set to go. I assume they're all expert sailors? And since there is a German battleship cruising off the coast of Scotland, I expect they'll try to sail it out of the lock and rendezvous at sea.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Did you say try to?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: I would suggest you get your things together. Mycroft will be here to take you into custody.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: I never had you fooled for a moment, did I? You knew right from the beginning -- when the cabbie brought me to Baker Street.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Let me see -- not quite that soon.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: It's so funny. I asked for this assignment, you know. I was scheduled to go to Japan, but I couldn't resist the challenge of coming up against the best. I'm sorry I didn't give you a closer game.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Close enough.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: You're just being kind.   I failed miserably.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: We all have occasional failures. Fortunately, Dr. Watson never writes about mine.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes!   Holmes!

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes!

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes, I saw it again -- that thing -- it came from the castle -- it's out there --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: It was out there. Now it's gone.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Gone?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Forever.   Look for yourself.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: A bottle of champagne?... and a Bible?...

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: That's all that's left of H.M.S. Jonah.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: It would seem that somebody carelessly loosened the bolts of the submersible. What a fitting end for Trappists -- now they are resting in eternal silence at the bottom of the lake.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Do you know what he's talking about?

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Fraulein von Hoffmanstal?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Yes, Mr. Holmes. I'm all ready.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: If there's one thing I like about the Prussians, it's their punctuality.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: If there's one thing I dislike about the British, it's their climate. I understand your jails are quite damp -- and your heating facilities totally inadequate.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: They are. But you're not going to jail. You're going back to Germany.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Germany?

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: You will be conducted to the Swiss-German border, and be exchanged for one of our agents -- a man named Ibbetson.

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Don't thank me. Thank my brother.      It was his idea.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Don't you agree, Sherlock?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: And better than some consulting detectives.

Speaker: mycroft
Dialogue: Shall we?

Speaker: gabrielle
Dialogue: Gentlemen.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: All right, Holmes -- you don't have to explain anything to me, if you don't want to.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: I appreciate that, Watson.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: After all, I'm only your official biographer --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Anyway, I don't think she'd care to have this story spread all over Strand Magazine.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: The public has a right to know these things. If she's a German spy, why should we concern ourselves about her feelings?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: If I promised not to write a word about it, would you enlighten me? As your friend -- as your valet --

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Quiet. I'm trying to read a personal message.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: A message?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: What is she saying?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Auf Wiedersehn.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Auf Weider---? The nerve!

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: H'mmm. A letter from the Diogenes Club.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Maybe Mycroft is putting you up for membership.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: If only to have the distinct pleasure of blackballing his brother.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Aren't you going to finish your breakfast?

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Holmes -- I'm terribly sorry about this.

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: Where is it, Watson?

Speaker: holmes
Dialogue: You're getting better.

Speaker: lestrade
Dialogue: Good morning, Watson.  Just happened to be in the neighborhood, and I thought --

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: What is it this time, Inspector Lestrade?

Speaker: lestrade
Dialogue: We've had three rather nasty murders in Whitechapel. All ladies of  easy virtue. You may read something about it -- the newspapers are referring to the killer as Jack the Ripper.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Yes, I think I have.

Speaker: lestrade
Dialogue: Some of us at Scotland Yard were wondering if perhaps Mr. Holmes would be willing to --

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Lestrade. But at the moment, Holmes is working on another problem.

Speaker: lestrade
Dialogue: Oh... Well, I just thought it was the kind of case that might interest him. I dare say we can solve it without his help.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Oh, I'm sure you will.

Speaker: watson
Dialogue: Good day, Lestrade.
